Author: ALee
Content:
Mixx received LA Times funding within the last two months, but they have been around much longer. They're one of the startups in Virginia that much of the valley doesn't hear about.

One of their front end developers is a good friend of mine and I complained about the same thing about their groups/sub-reddits, etc. Funny thing is that I think reddit did most of this already, but it's just been tougher for them to be on the radar now that they're part of a larger media conglomerate (no matter how startup-like they are, drankkit anyone?)

Author: objectiveous
Content: IMO, it's a question of accountability. Decide first who is accountable for the success of the effort and the give that person the power to make the decision.

Author: edw519
Content: Aren't they all?  Pretty people don't need the internet.  They just go out in the real world and take their pick.  (Or so I've heard)

Author: edw519
Content:
Stupid follow-up question for everyone (with no right answer):

Of all of your resources (time, knowledge, attention, focus, energy, passion,...), what would you say is the "split" between application development and infrastructure building/maintenance?

For me: 90% app dev, 10% infrastructure. I didn't realize people spent so much resource on the latter.

Author: edw519
Content:
"I'm not sure that learning a new language while developing for final product is a good idea"

I KNOW it's not. I wasted 6 months on this same stupid question before coding it in what I knew best first. Don't make the same mistake as me.

Minimize the number of unknowns. Your app is unknown. That should be the only unknown. Forget about scaling for now. Forget about learning new technology for now. They'll just take focus and energy away from the only important thing now: getting Your App 1.0 up and running. Code it with what you already know. When you're ready to rewrite it later (you know you'll have to), post your question again.
